channel.title: Engadget
channel.description: Engadget is a web magazine with obsessive daily coverage of everything new in gadgets and consumer electronics
channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2021 Yahoo! Inc. All rights reserved

item.title: The National Archives won't be able to host Donald Trump's tweets on Twitter
item.description: Twitter won't allow the National Archives to host an archive of Trump's tweets on the social media network.

item.title: Tesla refunded customers who were charged twice for their cars
item.description: The Tesla customers who were charged twice for their EVs did get their money back, eventually.

item.title: MST3K's latest kickstarter is funding a new streaming platform
item.description: Mystery Science Theater 3000 returns to Kickstarter to fund its latest comeback, with greater aspirations this time around.

item.title: Twitch will ban users for serious offline misconduct
item.description: An expanded safety policy targets major safety risks to the Twitch community that emerge offline or on other platforms.

item.title: TikTok is adding six new interactive, musical filters
item.description: Starting today, TikTok is rolling out new music-themed filters that promise greater interactivity.

item.title: Eufy's two-camera baby monitor kit is $50 off again at Amazon
item.description: Eufy's popular baby monitor kit is back down to its lowest price

item.title: Apple's Find My app officially works with non-Apple devices
item.description: Apple is expanding its Find My network to include third-party devices.

item.title: Google's virtual I/O developer conference kicks off on May 18
item.description: The show will kick off May 18 and will be hosted online only, as we continue to wait out the end of the pandemic. It will also be free to attend.

item.title: Spotify rolls out its own hands-free voice assistant on iOS and Android
item.description: You can ask the app to play a song, artist or playlist after saying 'Hey, Spotify.'

item.title: YouTube is once again the most popular social media platform
item.description: Facebook and YouTube are still the most dominant social media platforms in the United States, but only YouTube is still growing.

item.title: T-Mobile's wireless home internet service launches today
item.description: After a lengthy trial, T-Mobile Home Internet service is now available to 30 million Americans.

item.title: Amazon Music for iOS and Android has a simplified Car Mode
item.description: It has streamlined controls and custom presets for playlists, stations and albums.

item.title: Facebook adds Zoom video calls to Portal for TVs
item.description: Facebook's Portal TV now supports Zoom and GoToMeeting, bringing video calls to the biggest screen in your home.

item.title: Pinterest launches a Creator Fund to pay influencers
item.description: Pinterest is launching a “Creator Fund” to pay a small group of influencers to create content for the platform. It also wrote a "Creator Code" to keep its influencers positive.

item.title: This revolutionary weight loss program is backed by psychology
item.description: Noom helps you lose weight and learn more about yourself in the process.

item.title: Sorry, judges, encrypted chat is not like a private thought
item.description: A judge recently claimed that encrypted messages are similar to private thoughts. We, and the FBI, bed to differ.

item.title: Samsung’s new Galaxy A phone lineup includes its cheapest 5G model yet
item.description: Between the Galaxy S21 series and the foldables it plans to release later this year, Samsung is pretty much set with premium smartphones. For anyone who doesn’t want to drop flagship levels of cash, though, Samsung just pulled back the curtain on a bevy of new affordable models for the US, including the company’s cheapest 5G smartphone yet.

item.title: THX's Onyx is a tiny USB-C headphone DAC that supports master-quality audio
item.description: THX's first consumer hardware is a portable USB-C DAC that gives wired headphones a powerful audio upgrade for $200.

item.title: European privacy group claims Android's ad-tracking code is illegal
item.description: A privacy campaigner has filed a complaint in France claiming that Google's Android Advertising Identifier violates EU law.

item.title: Ring brings its radar-scanning tech to a floodlight camera
item.description: The new floodlight camera lets you see a breadcrumb trail of someone's path to your door.

item.title: Tesla takes to Chinese social media to ease local spying fears
item.description: Tesla is using its Chinese social media page to assuage local spying fears after its cars were banned from the country's military facilities and select state-owned companies.

item.title: Alienware's M15 and Dell's G15 gaming laptops are getting AMD Ryzen CPUs
item.description: Dell is finally bringing AMD CPUs back to its gaming laptops on the Alienware M15 and Dell G15.

item.title: The best wireless headphones you can buy right now
item.description: Here's a list of the best wireless headphones you can buy right now, as reviewed by Engadget editors.

item.title: UK launches new watchdog to govern the dominance of Big Tech
item.description: The UK has launched its Digital Markets Unit, a new watchdog tasked with ensuring that the likes of Facebook and Google cannot abuse their power to block out competitors.

item.title: The Morning After: Our verdict on the Sonos Roam
item.description: Sonos just delivered the Roam, but it has a more secretive speaker on the way.
